review.title: Decision making via semi-supervised machine learning techniques
review.abstract: Semi-supervised learning (SSL) is a class of supervised learning tasks and techniques that also exploits the unlabeled data for training. SSL significantly reduces labeling related costs and is able to handle large data sets. The primary objective is the extraction of robust inference rules. Decision support systems (DSSs) who utilize SSL have significant advantages. Only a small amount of labelled data is required for the initialization. Then, new (unlabeled) data can be utilized and improve system's performance. Thus, the DSS is continuously adopted to new conditions, with minimum effort. Techniques which are cost effective and easily adopted to dynamic systems, can be beneficial for many practical applications. Such applications fields are: (a) industrial assembly lines monitoring, (b) sea border surveillance, (c) elders' falls detection, (d) transportation tunnels inspection, (e) concrete foundation piles defect recognition, (f) commercial sector companies financial assessment and (g) image advanced filtering for cultural heritage applications.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: In this section, we will briefly attempt to capture the idea behind Semi-Supervised Learning (SSL). As we will see, the basic idea is the need for evolution, existing techniques, in a cost-effective way. It is extremely important to deal with the wealth of data in a meaningful way in order to (a) improve the performance of the model and (b) minimize the interventions of the experts. Thus, the first steps in the SSL field began around 1960, when scientists began to use new (i.e. previously unseen, undescribed) data to improve the capabilities of their models. Since then, and to this day, SSL field continues to encompass, motivated by the abundance of data of our age.

sections.heading: 1.1 Definition of semi-supervised machine learning
sections.text: SSL is the task of machine learning to derive a function from marked and unmarked data. SSL thus falls between unsupervised learning, e.g. (Ranzato et al., 2007; Konstantinos Makantasis et al., 2013), and supervised learning, e.g. (Doulamis et al., 2003; Kosmopoulos et al., 2011). The basic idea lies in the usefulness of unmarked data (Seeger, 2001); when used in conjunction with a small amount of marked data, the performance of the model can be significantly improved in terms of accuracy, precision, etc. The use of unmarked data is based on various assumptions regarding its structure and characteristic space properties. Overall, there are three main assumptions that can be used either alone or in combination. Assuming that at least one suitable regulator is formed and used over the unmarked data, the model is trained and the overall performance evaluated.SSL is used as a problem solution or as a combination.

sections.heading: 1.2 A brief history
sections.text: The concept of such an approach was fairly simple; learning a model, using it with new data to produce results, and using the new results to further explore the model, the latter appearing as transductive learning (Vapnik and Chervonenkis, 1974; Vapnik and Sterin, 1977), in which case the labeling process only occurs on the currently available (unlabeled) data. Unlike inductive inferences, no general decision has been made. In the 1970s, the Fisher estimation problem appeared to be a linear discriminatory rule with unlabeled data (Hosmer, 1973; Medicare achlan, 1977; Medicare achlan and Ganesalingam, 1982; O'neill, 1978). The main approach involved mixing Gaussians and the expectation of maximized algorithms into an iterative phase.

sections.heading: 1.3 Practical value of SSL
sections.text: Acquisition of marked data for a learning problem often requires a skilled human agent (e.g., to transcribe an audio segment, the background in an image, etc.) or a physical experiment (e.g., determining the 3D structure of a protein to determine whether there is oil in a particular place).The costs associated with the labeling process can therefore make a fully labeled training set unfeasible, while acquiring unlabeled data is relatively inexpensive. In such situations, SSL can be of great practical value. SSL is also of theoretical interest in the field and as a model for human learning. A great advantage is the ease of implementing existing techniques; SSL can be directly or indirectly involved in a machine learning task. Semi-monitored SVMs are a classic example of the direct use of SSL assumptions in the miniature world.

sections.text: The arrangement of cluster structure identification points (OPTICS) is an algorithm for determining density-based clusters in spatial data (Ankerst et al., 1999), i.e. for detecting meaningful clusters in data of varying densities. sections.heading: 3.2.4 Kennard–Stone algorithm
sections.text: The classic KenStone algorithm (Kennard and Stone, 1969) is a uniform mapping algorithm; it provides a flat distribution of the data. It is a sequential method that should uniformly cover the experimental region. It consists in selecting, as the next sample (candidate object), the one that is furthest away from the already selected objects (calibration objects). As a starting point, we select either the two objects that are furthest away from each other, or preferably the one that is closest to the meaning. Of all candidate points, the one that is furthest away from the already selected is selected and added to the calibration point. To do this, we measure the distance from each candidate point 0 to each point that has already been selected and determine which is the smallest, i.e. min 0). From these, we select the one for which is the maximum distance: the point is the calibration point.

sections.text: Most of the application scenarios presented in this thesis were actually classification problems. As such, the primary tool for performance evaluation became the confusion matrix. Other significant performance indicators were execution time, complexity of algorithms, and dimensionality and separability. However, common desktop computers were used in all developed systems. Given these values, we are able to calculate different performance indicators in relation to error detection performance.

sections.heading: 4 Labeled data selection impact in credit risk assessment
sections.text: In this chapter we emphasize the credit risk assessment of Greek companies (commercial sector) for the period 2006-2009. The proposed approach includes synergistic models from both sample and classification. In particular, we show the impact of the sample on the performance of the models. A variety of sampling methods are used to evaluate the descriptive capabilities of small training sets, with a classifier raging from traditional models, e.g. logistic regression, to advanced soft computing techniques, e.g. artificial neural networks. The results provide a comprehensive common assessment of the synergies of the sample classification models. Comparisons are based on various quantitative performance metrics, including the required initialization time. Simulation results suggest that there is no optimal choice regarding data sampling and also no classification approach. There are a variety of synergistic evaluation models; the best alternative is always defined by the execution time, for example.

sections.heading: 4.1 Introduction
sections.text: Credit risk analysis is a fundamental and challenging topic in the field of financial risk management and has been the main topic of the financial and banking industry in recent decades. Credit rating models have been extensively used to evaluate the credit risk of companies, and they can classify applicants as either accepted or rejected according to the criteria studied. However, in recent decades, a large sum of credit risk decision models has been proposed and evaluated (Marqués et al., 2013; Thomas, 2000).Existing approaches to credit risk assessment include mainly linear discrimination techniques and logistic regression (Vojtek and Kocenda, 2006; Zeng and Gao, 2009), the next neighborhood analysis (Henley and Hand, 1996), Bayesian networks (Pavlenko and Chernyak, 2010), artificial neural networks and logistic regression (Vojtek and Kocenda, 2006; Zeng and Gao, 2009) Attression Attression, Attression, Attression Attression, Attression, Attression Attression, Attression Attression, and Logistic, 2010), Attression Attression, Attression, Attression, Attression, Attression, Attression, Attression Attression, 2010, Attression, Attression, Attression Attression, 2010, Attression, Attression, Attression Attression, 2010, Attression, Attression, Attression Attression, 2010, Attression, Attression, Attression, 2006;

sections.heading: 4.3 Proposed methodology
sections.text: This chapter adopts a two-step process to assess the credit risk of enterprises. Step one involves sampling data, i.e. selecting the most descriptive representatives of the available dataset. Step two uses popular data mining algorithms to analyze both the efficiency of the sampling systems and the synergies of the previous step. Selecting a subset of individuals to be calculated within a currently available dataset, plus the calculation costs (in terms of time spent during the initialization process), is a critical step in analyzing the efficiency of sampling systems and the synergies. Selecting individuals to estimate the characteristics of newly emerging data is capable of identifying the most representative cases and effectively addressing class imbalances when the selective nature of default models is affected.

sections.heading: 4.6 Conclusions and future work
sections.text: Adequate train data sets greatly improve the classification performance of each model. Moreover, the results of the sampling methods have been exceptional, despite heuristic rules governing the definition of the parameters. Further investigation of the parameters will lead to even better performance. Furthermore, there are many opportunities to exploit unlabeled data as long as good characteristics are available. These positive preliminary results suggest that there is a lot of room for future research that has the potential to offer many new skills and insights into credit risk modeling. A first obvious direction would be to use richer predictor attributes, taking into account variables related to the corporate sector, variables related to non-financial characteristics of companies (e.g. age, composition of the board), stock market data, corporate governance indicators, macroeconomic variables, and variables that indicate the dynamics of companies "financial data (e.g. growth rates).

sections.heading: 5 Deep-learning, vision-based tunnel inspection
sections.text: In this chapter, we look at the detection of defects in tunnel concrete by visual cues. It is a typical two-tier identification problem, where we examine the performance of different approaches using the raw input of a single monocular camera. Specifically, we use a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) to construct high-grade properties, and as a classifier, we opt for a Multi-Layer Perceptron (MLP) based on its global functional approximation characteristics. In accordance with the approach shown above, our method achieves real-time prediction due to the feed-forward nature of CNNs and MLPs. CNN is evaluated using a variety of machine learning approaches, including SSL techniques. The SSL paradigms tested were not suitable for the specific task as shown below. There were three major drawbacks: low functional quality, long execution times and hardware requirements. Specifically, for the present image, low characteristics are not suitable for the specific task, even if the small amount of RAM requires a large amount of RAM.

sections.heading: 5.1 Introduction
sections.text: Civilian infrastructures are increasingly deteriorating (e.g. aging processes, environmental factors), requiring verification and evaluation. Currently, tunnel construction inspection is mainly carried out through tunnel-wide visual observations by inspectors who detect, evaluate and then categorize the liner based on its severity. Furthermore, the visual inspection (VI) process is slow, labor-intensive and subjective (depending on experience and fatigue), and occurs when working in an unpleasant environment and unpleasant conditions (Yu et al., 2007). Furthermore, liner condition assessment is empirical and incomplete and lacking in any technical analysis; it is therefore unreliable. Approaches that use automated procedures for VI of concrete infrastructures are specifically aimed at detecting defects and evaluating structures. In this direction, such methods are aimed at image processing and machine learning techniques.

sections.heading: 5.2.2 Visual Information Modeling for Tunnel Inspection
sections.text: In this section, we describe the process of encoding visual information. This process takes place using low-level characteristics. There are two main reasons why we have used such characteristics: First, similar characteristics have been used by many researchers (e.g. (Abdel-Qader et al., 2003; German et al., 2012; Halfawy and Hengmeechai, 2014; Koch and Brilakis, 2011; Son et al., 2012). Second, such low-level characteristics are calculated based on raw data and are mathematically cheaper than other high-level characteristics. It should be noted that these characteristics are used by CNN to construct hierarchically high-level characteristics. They are not used directly for classification purposes. Using low-level feature extraction techniques, each pixel is described by a feature vector. = [1,...,,,], where, = 1,... scalars correspond to the presence and size of the characteristics that we use in detecting at a lower level ().

sections.heading: 5.2.2.1 Edges
sections.text: In order to successfully use the edges of an image, the system must be able to detect them in a very precise way on the one hand, and maintain their size on the other hand. Therefore, we have combined the operators Canny and Sobel. The operator Canny (McIlhagga, 2011) is a very precise edge detector that outputs zeros and ones for the absence and presence of edges respectively. On the other hand, the operator Sobel (Yasri et al., 2008) measures the strength of the detected edges. If you multiply the output of two operators pixels by pixel, the system is able to detect edges in a very precise way while maintaining their size at the same time. If we call the operators Canny and Sobel for the image, then the edges defined as: = (matrix) have the same dimensions with the image and its elements () correspond to the size of an image edge at high frequency (2) at the same frequency.

sections.heading: 5.2.2.3 Entropy
sections.text: Image tropy quantifies the information encoded in an image, i.e. the amount of information that can be encoded by a compression algorithm. Image tropy can be interpreted as a statistical measure of randomness that can be used to characterize the texture of the input image. (41) Deep-learning, vision-based tunnel inspectionDECISION MAKING VIA SEMI-SUPERVISED MACHINE LEARNING TECHNIQUES | Ph.D. ThesisImages, which represent large homogeneous regions, present low entropy, while highly textured images represent high entropy.

sections.heading: 5.2.2.4 Histogram of Oriented Gradients
sections.text: HOG is a popular, dense feature descriptor (Dalal and Triggs, 2005) used for object recognition. It uses image gradients to capture contour, silhouette and texture information to generate an encoding that is sensitive to local image content while remaining resistant to small changes in pose or appearance.

sections.heading: 5.2.2.5 Texture
sections.text: A Gabor filter is characterized by frequency and orientation. Frequency and orientation representations of Gabor filters are similar to those of the human visual system, and they have proven to be particularly suitable for displaying and discriminating textures. In the spatial range, a 2D Gabor filter is a Gaussian core function modulated by a sine wave. In our implementation, we used Gabor filters with different frequencies and orientations to extract low characteristics from the image. Specifically, we used twelve Gabor filters with orientations 0, 30, 60, 60, and 90 and frequencies 0.0, 0.1, and 0.4. Following the above-mentioned process, we construct 16 low characteristics for an image. By combining these characteristics with the raw pixel intensity, the feature vector takes the form of a 1 x 17 vector containing the respective image points.

sections.heading: 5.2.3 Leaning model
sections.text: As already mentioned, CNN's load-bearing filters and pooling operations apply to their input, resulting in a hierarchy of increasingly complex characteristics. Convolution layers consist of a rectangular grid of neurons (filters), each taking input from rectangular sections of the previous layer. Each convolution is followed by a pooling layer, which divides the output of the precise convolution layer block by block, generating a scalar output for each block. Formally, considering the -th output of a given convolution layer as its filters are determined by weights and bias, you get the g (((Wk x) ij + bk) (5,4), where the property stands for the input of the revolutionary layer and the indices and location correspond to the input in which that of the filter is plotted.

sections.heading: 5.2.3.1 Learning model parameterization
sections.text: The visual information of each raw image is encoded using the techniques described in paragraph 5.2.2, resulting in a 3D tensor measuring 17 x, representing the width and height of the raw input image. This tensor is divided into 1 x 5 x 5 overlapping windows that serve as input to CNN.43 depth learning, vision-based tunnel inspection DECISION VIA SEMI-SUPERVISED MACHINE LEARNING TECHNIQUES | Ph.D. ThesisThe input is fed into the second convective layer using 30 traceable filters measuring 3 x 3. The output of the first convective layer is a 3D matrix measuring 30 x 3 x 3, as we do not consider the boundary of the window during folding. The output of this layer is fed into the second convective layer as input and is covered with 60 tractive features of the dimension 3 x 3. The output of the second layer is covered as a MV layer.

sections.heading: 5.2.4 Possible limitations
sections.text: The visual complexity of the defects differs significantly between the inspection sites, as there is no guarantee that initial pre-processing (i.e. low extracted features) will be sufficient as initial (basic) descriptors, and requires additional computational effort. This disadvantage is taken into account in the work of (Protopapadakis and Doulamis, 2015b), where input fields are taken from the raw image. Another problem is the initialization setup; a carefully annotated image set is required to initialize the detectors, as we have a pixel level evaluation process, which is time-consuming and prone to segmentation errors (human). SSL annotation schemes such as in paragraph 8.4 are not applicable in this case due to low descriptive capabilities of the extracted features.

sections.heading: 5.3 Performance evaluation
sections.text: The proposed system was developed on a conventional laptop with i7 CPU, 8GB of RAM using MatLab software and Theano library (Bastien et al., 2012) in Python. CNN was compared to well-known pattern recognition techniques (as described in paragraph 3.1) based on craftsmanship characteristics. To make a fair comparison, we used the same characteristics for each of these techniques as in paragraph 5.2.2.

sections.heading: 5.3.1 Dataset description
sections.text: All images are taken from the tunnels of the Egnatia motorway in Greece. There was a wide variety of tunnels available for recording. Raw tunnel and annotated ground images with a resolution of 800 x 600 pixels were provided. No special setup took place during the imaging, i.e. images are taken from any angle and distance from the tunnel surface. As defects cover very few areas, we had to balance the train and the test kits. In total, more than 100,000 samples were classified; the evaluation (test) set was 30% of the same. The performance parameters are shown in Table 5.1 for all proposed approaches. A description of the metrics is given in Section 3.3, Table 3.1. Figures of the model output can be found in Figure 5.5. In this case, we have two possible classes: cracks or non-cracks, which are referred to as positive (P) or negative (N). Confusion matrix and calculated performance parameters are explained in Figure 5.5.

sections.heading: 5.3.2 Experimental results
sections.text: The results of Table 5.1 suggest that low features are appropriate for the general defect detection task. However, since such traditional machine learning approaches can support a tunnel inspection process, Figure 5.5 suggests otherwise. The explanation for such contradictory results lies in the descriptive capabilities of the features. Lever-arm features that form the training and evaluation sets are calculated using a series of initial frames. However, the slightest change in the imaging process results in significant changes in low characteristic values. As such, angles, brightness or focal lenses alter the output of the detector. A larger dataset is not the solution, as the possible combinations of image acquisition parameters are infinite; we have neither the resources nor the time required for such a task. Additional features do not help as we have the "curse of dimensionality," as illustrated in Figure 2.2.4. CNN is a good alternative, as the highly rational features used can address all of the problems mentioned above in a time span issue.

sections.heading: 5.4 Conclusions & future work
sections.text: In this chapter, we highlight the suitability of defect inspection architectures for the tunnel problem. The proposed approach surpasses a variety of known approaches without making assumptions about the given images (e.g. minimum resolution, camera angles, etc.).46 The hierarchical construction of complex high-level features in an automated manner leads to a better classification than traditional hand-crafted features, while minimizing the effort of feature design compared to traditional approaches.46 Decision-making using semi-supervised machine learning techniques Eftychios Protopapadakis | TECHNICAL UNIVERSITY OF CRETEChapter VI: Industrial Workflow MonitoringIf everyone thinks the same, then no one thinks so. sections.heading: 6 A hybrid, self-trained model for industrial workflow monitoring
sections.text: In this case, we propose an ANN-based scheme for classifying assembly processes, based on video data from the Nissan plant. This is a self-trained SSL approach. It is based on (a) a non-linear classifier built using an island genetic algorithm, (b) a similarity-based classifier, and (c) a decision-making mechanism that uses the results of the classifiers in a semi-supervised manner and minimizes expert intervention. Such a methodology supports visual monitoring of industrial environments by providing essential information to supervisors and supporting their work.

sections.heading: 6.1 Introduction
sections.text: Visual monitoring is an important task within complex industrial environments; it must provide fast and accurate detection of production and assembly processes. When it comes to intelligent monitoring of large companies or factories, the importance of behavioral detection relates to the safety and security of personnel, reducing the cost of bad products, production planning, and the quality of the production process. In most approaches, the goal is either to detect activities that may deviate from the standard, or to classify some isolated activities (Kim and Ling, 2009; Turaga et al., 2008). Modern techniques are based on supervised training, using large data sets. The need for a significant amount of tagged data during the training phase makes classification data expensive. In addition, this data requires expert knowledge that further increases costs.

sections.heading: 6.2 Proposed methodology
sections.text: The approach presented is based on an innovative, self-improving cognitive system based on a semi-supervised learning strategy: first, appropriate visual characteristics are extracted using various techniques, and then visual histograms are generated using these characteristics to address temporal variations in the execution of different cases of the same industrial workflow.The histograms generated are fed as inputs into a nonlinear classifier. At the heart of the system is the automatic, self-improving methodology of the classifier. Specifically, we start feeding the classifier with a small but sufficient number of training samples (labeled data), and then test the classifier against new, unlabeled data. If certain criteria are met, the classifier automatically selects suitable data from the set of unlabeled data for further training, defining the criteria so that only the most trusted, unlabeled data is used on the new training setup.

sections.heading: 6.2.1 The island genetic algorithm
sections.text: The usefulness of genetic algorithms (GAs) is generally accepted (Whitley et al., 1999).The island of GA uses a population of alternative individuals on each of the islands. Each individual is an FFNN. While epochs combine the parameters of the networks in different ways to achieve a suitable topology, a pair of FFNs (parents) is combined to create two new FFNs (children).Children randomly inherit their topology characteristics from their parents. Under certain circumstances, each of these characteristics may change (mutation).The quartet, parents and children, are subsequently evaluated and remain the two best by updating the population of the island.An era has passed when all members of the population participated in the above procedure. To curb the genetic drift, population exchange between the islands may occur every four epochs. The algorithm ends when all epochs have passed.

sections.heading: 6.2.2 The nonlinear classifier
sections.text: In the proposed approach, the nonlinear classifier is a genetically optimized (i.e. topologically) upstream neural network according to the training sample. The topology of the neural network is defined by the number of hidden layers, neurons on each layer, and activation functions (as described in paragraph 3.1.6). All of the above, as well as the number of training periods, have been optimized using an island genetic algorithm. After the training phase is complete, we will start feeding in the optimal unlabeled data of the network. As the output vector of the classifier contains different values (its actual size is 1 x 7 as the number of possible tasks), the output element with the highest value is converted to 1, while all the others are set to 0. This only happens if the highest value is reliable. Conditions for the reliability of the classifier are explained in the following section.

sections.heading: 6.2.3 The semi-supervised approach
sections.text: The main problem in order to improve the performance of the network is the reliability of the label of the new data derived from the pool of undescribed persons, the exploitation of the performance in the already described data. In this approach, the output reliability is carried out by comparing the absolute value of the largest output element with the second highest criterion, the results being considered vague as the output quantity is considered reliable. An unattended algorithm (e.g. the means) is used in the case of ambiguous results to support the decision. In particular, the undescribed input size is considered a vector that compares the vague output with all the described data.

sections.heading: 6.2.4 The decision mechanism
sections.text: According to the non-linear classification results, there are three possible cases (scenarios): 1. The network has made a robust decision that should not be contradicted. Therefore, the unlabeled data will be used for training, but they will not be included in the first training. 2. The results are blurred, in other words, the difference between the two largest prices does not exceed the thresholds. Therefore, an expert is called in and determines where to classify the video. If both systems point to the same thing, the unlabeled data will be used for further training, but they will not be included in the first training. 3. The two classifiers do not agree. Therefore, an expert is called in and determines where to classify the video. This video will be added to the first training data set. The combination of these cases leads to a semi-monitored decision mechanism. 3. Define thresholds that will occur from the above scenarios. The threshold is defined as a percentage of the difference between the vector at the two largest starting prices.

sections.heading: 6.2.5 Possible limitations
sections.text: Characteristics cannot guarantee smooth performance; due to the similarity of labor movements across many activities, there is a trade-off between discriminatory skills between tasks. Such a disadvantage can be solved either by incorporating information from past frames (Protopapadakis et al., 2013).In addition, system initialization requires descriptive data from all tasks. In other cases, the involved classifiers are likely to perform an incorrect classification and retrain the model with them. Therefore, a significant deterioration in performance is to be expected. Different camera positions or data from multiple cameras can further improve the performance of the model.

sections.heading: 6.3 Feature extraction
sections.text: All videos use integral features such as Pixel Change History (PCH), which eliminates the drawbacks of local features, but also requires a much less tiring computational process for their extraction (Ahad et al., 2010). A very positive attribute of such representations is that they can easily capture the history of a task being performed, and these images can then be converted into a vector-based representation using the Zernike moments (Hwang and Kim, 2006) up to the sixth order as applied in (Kosmopoulos et al., 2011). The video functions, once exported, had a 2-dimensional matrix representation of the form m × l, where m denotes the size of the 1 × m vectors created with Zernike moments, and l the number of such vectors.51 A hybrid, self-trained model for monitoring industrial workflows.

sections.heading: 6.4 Performance evaluation
sections.text: The proposed system was developed on a conventional laptop with i3 CPU and 4GB of RAM using MatLab software. The results shown below are the averages after a total of 150 simulations. In each simulation, a different set of highlighted data was selected.

sections.heading: 6.4.1 Data set description
sections.text: The proposed system was tested on the basis of the NISSAN video dataset (Voulodimos et al., 2011), which refers to a real industrial process related to the assembly of car parts. Seven different, time-repeating workflows were identified that utilize the knowledge of industrial engineers. Challenging visual effects occur, such as background confusion / motion, heavy closures and lighting fluctuations. 52 Decision making using Semi-Supervised Machine Learning TechniquesEftychios Protopapadakis | TECHNICAL UNIVERSITY OF CRETEThe production cycle on the industrial line included tasks such as picking several parts from shelves and placing them on a designated cell a few meters away from where the welding took place. Each of the above tasks was considered a class of behavioural patterns that needed to be recognized.

sections.heading: 6.4.2 Model initialization and adaptation in new data
sections.text: First, the best possible network is generated using the island's genetic algorithm and 40% of the available data, the remaining data is fed gradually into the network, and the overall performance of the sample is calculated. In any case, all data that activated scenario # 3 is excluded, and then the network is processed sequentially with the residual data. If the network's suggestions are correct, it will perform better as more training data (without those from scenario # 3) has been used for further training, resulting in unlabeled data falling below 60% and training data continuing to rise. The above procedure ends after five iterations, at which point the ratio between the sample data and the sample data does not exceed 50%. 54 Decision Making via Semi-Supervised Machine Learning TechniquesEftychios Protopapadakis | TECHNICAL UNIVERSITY OF CRETE

sections.heading: 6.4.3 Performance
sections.text: It seems that a neural network with two hidden layers using hyperbolic tangent sigmoid or log sigmoid transmission functions, with an average of nine neurons in each layer, is the most appropriate solution, and the proposed system is able to use the new knowledge to its advantage. Overall performance increases by iterating using small amounts of data, as shown in Figure 6.6. In fact, the system achieved a 75% correct classification by using an additional 10% of the videos. This is important because the system saves time and resources during initialization and provides good classification percentages using less than 50% of the available data. The impact of training periods on overall performance is shown in Figure 6.7. There appears to be a trade-off between total and individual task classification. Although 200 to 300 training periods provide significant classification accuracy, further training partially increases accuracy only in certain tasks with respect to other costs.

sections.heading: 6.5 Conclusions & future Work
sections.text: In this paper, we have proposed a new framework for behavioural recognition in workflows. The above methodology addresses an important problem in visual recognition: it requires a small training sample to efficiently categorise different workflows in the assembly. Such a methodology will support visual monitoring of industrial environments by providing essential information to supervisors and supporting their work.Improvements can be made at any stage of the system to further refine the performance of the system.Future work will be based on the use of different classifiers (e.g. neuro-fuzzy, linear support vector machines) and decision mechanisms (e.g. choice-based).In addition, instead of using all frameworks of a specific task to create classifiers, only a subset of them can be used as equivalent results.55 Improving the quality of life of older people DECISION MAKING VIA SEMI-SUPERVISED MACHINLENING TEQUALION.55

sections.heading: 7 Life quality improvement for elder people
sections.text: In this chapter, we will create a transductive classifier to determine whether or not we have the fall of a person. Falls have been reported as the main cause of injury-related visits to emergency rooms and the primary etiology of fatalities in the elderly. Therefore, the development of robust home monitoring systems is of great importance. In the work of (Makantasis et al., 2015b), such a system is presented that attempts to address the problem of fall detection through visual features. At the same time, the proposed methodology uses a fast, real-time subtraction algorithm based on motion information in the scene and pixel intensity that is able to function properly in dynamically changing visual conditions to detect the foreground object. At the same time, it utilizes the actions of 3D space through automatic camera calibration to increase the robustness of fall detection algorithms based on semi-supervised learning approaches.

sections.heading: 7.1 Introduction
sections.text: In order to solve the problem, we must seek a solution that is tailored to the needs of patients.

sections.heading: 7.1.1 Place for improvement
sections.text: A new approach is presented that utilizes both 2D image analysis (monocular cameras) and the relationship between the camera coordinate system and real 3D space. Such an approach enables the detection of falls in real time and under dynamically changing visual conditions and achieves robustness through camera calibration and inverse perspective mapping using 3D physical space measurements. The fall detection scheme consists of a non-linear warning system (nLWS) based on a semi-supervised learning approach (SSL). The nLWS uses neural networks that are topologically optimized by using an Iceland GA. Unlike other 2D fall detection methods, the proposed system is very robust for a wider range of camera positions and mounts and its performance is not affected by the distance between the object and the surface objects required for extraction.

sections.heading: 7.2 Proposed methodology
sections.text: The proposed fall detection mechanism comprises three phases: a) foreground / background extraction and human detection; b) appropriate feature extraction; and c) application of the decision mechanism. The system approach is illustrated in Figure 7.1. The first step of our algorithm is to detect the persons in a scene for each captured image, and this can be done by applying image segmentation and background subtraction methods. Once the individuals are detected, the system tracks them and estimates their height in order to calculate vertical movement velocity and analyze their posture. In addition, the primary concern of a fall detection system is to achieve low false negative rates, i.e. its goal is to detect all fall events, even if some of them are not true (false alarms). Therefore, we prefer to exclude the third feature from our analysis.

sections.heading: 7.2.1 The self-training approach
sections.text: The process is mainly based on the cluster approach: the data tend to form discrete clusters, and the points in the same cluster are more likely to share a label. The overall concept is similar to the work of ()

sections.heading: 7.2.2 nLWS initialization
sections.text: First, the aforementioned data are divided into two classes, i.e. falls and non-falls, using a combination of different metrics based on a k-mean algorithm. Variation of the metrics includes: (a) the square Euclidean distance, (b) the sum of absolute differences, and (c) one minus the cosine of the included angle between the data points. Then, an assumption is made: the less element class is considered a case class. This assumption is justified by the fact that case events occur much less frequently than other ordinary activities. An FFNN is topologically optimized by entering the previously generated data. Inputs of size 3x1 are used to produce corresponding results of size 2x1.

sections.heading: 7.2.3 nLWS operation
sections.text: The functionality of nLWS is based on a simple scheme: if the output element corresponding to the fall class has a higher value than the element corresponding to the non-fall class, then a fall event occurred or will occur in the following 0.9 seconds, which, as already mentioned, is the average duration of a fall event.

sections.heading: 7.2.4 Possible limitations
sections.text: In complex environmental conditions, such as those that occur in bathrooms, the performance of our system should be examined more closely. This is because in such environments heavy closures are to be expected (bath curtains, vapors), not to mention humidity factors that can affect the performance of any visual sensor. We expect that our system can provide almost the same performance for normal activities as in other home spaces (crossing, walking), but special care should be taken in certain bathing conditions. Privacy is also an important issue. People are very hesitant to install surveillance equipment (especially cameras) in such private spaces. Please note that other types of sensors (e.g. depth sensors) can potentially improve system performance. Currently, however, these sensors can be used in close proximity (a few meters), making them less reliable for monitoring elderly people in their homes, especially for large spaces. In addition, their cost, although very affordable, is only a few times higher than that of our more expensive optical devices that are implanted for their large-scale health care.

sections.heading: 7.3 Feature extraction
sections.text: In this section we describe both 2D features and 3D features used by the proposed methodology. 2D features include the projected width-to-height ratio of the person and body orientation, while 3D features include vertical movement speed based on the actual elevation estimate of the person. All features are extracted using a simple monocular camera. Generally, there are no limitations on the maximum distance of the camera from the falling scene or resolution as long as the person spans a range of more than 40 pixels in each image to achieve robust segmentation of foreground objects.

sections.heading: 7.3.1 Image segmentation
sections.text: The first step is the image segmentation process to separate the foreground (i.e. the human) from the background (i.e. everything else).Lighting conditions in indoor environments can change dramatically and suddenly due to artificial light sources, while outdoor lighting typically changes progressively and slowly.In addition, outdoor environments have a more complicated background with higher background movements and moving objects compared to indoor environments.We test the following algorithms: a) Iterative background learning algorithm (ISL) presented in (N. Doulamis, 2010), b) Adaptive Student's-t Mixture Model background subtraction (ASMM) presented in (Makantasis et al., 2012) and c) Non-parametric background generation algorithm (nPBG) presented in (Liu et al., 2007).This choice is justified by the fact that ISL algorithms extract the foreground by learning the background information by intensifying the use of the background information in the ASM.

sections.heading: 7.3.2 Describing a fall
sections.text: The characteristics used to differentiate case studies are: vertical movement speed based on actual height, projected width and body orientation. You can capture the details of such a process in a time span of 20 to 30 seconds.

sections.heading: 7.4 Experimental results
sections.text: For the experimental process, we had to simulate the fall of a person, in each direction according to the camera position and normal everyday activities. There are also cases that may look like but are not real falls (Figure 7.3). The fall detection algorithm was tested under dynamically changing visual conditions, including lighting changes, confusing background and occlusions. The performance of the algorithm is shown in Figure 7.4; the results correspond to a video sequence of 1000 images containing 19 fall events. However, as the actor walked or stood most of the time, we retain only a few characteristic key images of the original material for visualization purposes. Its performance is influenced by the quality of the extracted features and subsequently by foreground extraction. Therefore, our system presents more robust performances for indoor environments. However, it should be noted that its performance is not affected by the human body size, because the threshold for discriminatory incidents is estimated as normal activities.

sections.heading: 7.5 Conclusions & future work
sections.text: Through self-calibration of the camera and perspective transformations, our system is able to use 3D measurements to increase its robustness. It works in real time and is able to detect over 90% of the case events in complex and dynamically changing visual conditions, while exhibiting a very low false positive rate. 63 The low computation and storage requirements make it suitable for large-scale implementations, not to mention its low cost, as simple cameras with low resolution are used, making it affordable for large-scale deployment. 63 The maritime surveillantDECISION MAKING VIA SEMI-SUPERVISED MACHINE LEARNING TECHNIQUES | Ph.D. Thesis Chapter VIII: Sea Border SurveiceIntelligence is the ability to adapt to change. Stephen Hawking, English theoretical physicist

sections.heading: 8 Maritime surveillance
sections.text: This chapter presents a vision-based maritime surveillance system using moving PTZ cameras, which combines a visual attention method that takes advantage of the visual features appropriate for the maritime environment with a suitable tracker. Such features do not require assumptions about environmental or visual conditions, and offline initialization is based on a large, semi-monitored technique to minimize the user's hassle. In particular, the scalable SSL approach is activated over the originally annotated training data set; it is therefore used only once in the offline initialization phase. The main goal is to minimize possible annotation errors that occurred during the creation phase of the training datas.The performance of the system was evaluated using videos from cameras placed in the port of Limassol and in the Venetian port of Chania. Results indicate a high recognition capability, despite dynamically changing visual conditions and real time of all types of ships.

sections.heading: 8.1 Introduction
sections.text: The management of emergency situations known to the maritime sector can be supported by advanced surveillance systems suitable for complex environments. Such systems vary from radar to video-based. However, the former has two major disadvantages (Zemmari et al., 2013); it is quite expensive and its performance is influenced by various factors (e.g. echoes of targets that are not of interest), the latter consisting of various techniques, each with specific advantages and disadvantages. The majority of such systems are controlled by humans, who are responsible for monitoring and evaluating numerous video feeds.Advanced surveillance systems should intelligently and meaningfully process and present collected sensor data in order to provide adequate information support to human decision-makers (Fischer and Bauer, 2010).The detection and tracking of ships is inherently dependent on dynamically varying visual conditions (e.g. different lighting and reflections of the sea).Thus, in order to successfully design a vision-based monitoring system, we must carefully define both its operational requirements and its requirements.

sections.heading: On the other hand, regardless of vessel type’s variation, there are four major descriptive categories. First
sections.text: The size ranges from jet skis to large cruise ships. Secondly, we have the speed of movement. Thirdly, 64 Decision Making via Semi-Supervised Machine Learning TechniquesEftychios Protopapadakis | TECHNICAL UNIVERSITY OF CRETEvessels move in each direction, depending on the camera position, and thus their angle varies from 0 to 360 °. Finally, there is the visibility of vehicles. Some ships have a good contrast to the sea water, others are intentionally camouflaged. A robust maritime surveillance system must be able to detect ships with the above characteristics.

sections.heading: 8.1.1 Related work
sections.text: This chapter focuses on the detection and tracking of targets within the range of the camera, rather than its trajectory pattern "investigation (Lei, 2013; Vandecasteele et al., 2013) or its classification into categories of interest (Maresca et al., 2010). The main purpose of the system is to assist end users in the monitoring of coastlines, regardless of existing conditions.Object recognition is a common approach with many variations; i.e. isotropic diffusion (Voles, 1999), which is also suitable only for horizontal and vertical edges, foreground object detection / image color segmentation fusion (Socek et al., 2005). In (Albrecht et al., 2011a; Albrecht et al., 2010) a maritime surveillance system focuses mainly on the search for regions in images where a high probability of a ship is present is proposed.

sections.heading: 8.1.2 Place for improvement
sections.text: A careful examination of the proposed methods suggests that certain issues need to be addressed. First, a system needs to combine both supervised and unsupervised tracking techniques to take advantage of all possible benefits. Second, since we are dealing with enormous amounts of available data, we need to minimize the effort required to initialize the system as much as possible. Innovation of our approach lies in creating a visual recognition system that is able to overcome the above difficulties by combining different, well-proven techniques while minimizing the effort during offline initialization by using a semi-supervised learning (SSL) technique suitable for large amounts of data. Unlike the approach of (Makantasis et al., 2013), the user needs to roughly segment a few images, i.e. use minimal effort to create an initial training set. Such a procedure can be easily implemented using the suggested areas according to the results of the unattended techniques.

sections.heading: 8.2 Proposed methodology
sections.text: The main objective is to detect and track maritime targets in real time. In this direction, an appearance-based approach is adopted to create visual attention maps that represent the probability of a target's presence in the scene. High probability implies a high degree of confidence in the presence of a maritime target. Visual attention maps are created solely based on the visual content of each image, in relation to its surrounding regions, or the entire image. Consequently, they do not take into account the temporal relationship between subsequent frames or any motion information displayed in the scene. Due to this limitation, the high probability is often assigned image regions that represent non-maritime targets (e.g. stationary land parts). To overcome this disadvantage, our system takes advantage of the temporal relationship between subsequent frames. Specifically, video blocks that contain a predefined number of frames, a supernumber of frames and cover a period of time can be used to intensify pixel modeling.

sections.heading: 8.2.1 Problem formulation
sections.text: The detection of maritime targets can be considered a problem of image classification. Therefore, we classify each pixel of the frame into one of two classes, and. If we () designate the label of the pixel (), the classification task for a frame can be formulated as follows: () = () () () () (8,1), where and for the height and width of the frame. Although a binary SVM can successfully transform the classification task in our case, a classification process should precede it.

sections.heading: 8.2.2 Possible limitations
sections.text: However, the suggested approach can be extended to higher resolution video images, as each feature can be extracted independently of each other, so the process of feature extraction can easily be paralleled with the help of multiple processing units (e.g. multiple CPU threads or GPU implementation).The vision approach is capable of detecting targets in a similar way to the human eye. As long as the camera is able to capture a vessel (i.e. a range of more than 40 pixels in the frame), the system is likely to detect it, regardless of weather conditions (e.g. rain, fog, waves, etc.).Obviously, the performance of the system decreases sharply in cases of low luminosity due to sensor-induced sensitivity limitations. Better sensors can partly deal with such problems, but this leads to higher hardware costs.Finally, SSL is used to refine the initial training test; it is not an image commentary mechanism.

sections.heading: 8.3 Feature extraction
sections.text: Potential targets in the maritime environment vary in size, either because of their physical size or because of the distance between them and the camera. Nevertheless, most of the feature detectors work as a kernel-based method and therefore prefer objects of a certain size. As in (Alexe et al., 2010; T. Liu et al., 2011) images must be presented at different scales to overcome this limitation. In our approach, a Gaussian image pyramid is used to provide scale-related inventory and take into account the relationship between adjacent pixels. Then, we have the traditional low-level features analysis. As in (Albrecht et al., 2011b) various low-level image features respond to different attributes of potential maritime targets. Thus, a combination of features can be exploited to reveal the presence of targets.

sections.heading: 8.3.1 Local descriptors
sections.text: A local descriptor is calculated for each of the extracted low-level features. Let's call the feature in question a feature that can correspond to the border, frequency, horizontal and vertical lines, color, or entropy. For the feature, the calculation of the local descriptor is derived from the feature's response image. As mentioned before, descriptors are calculated block by block. So, first, the feature's response image is divided into blocks of size 8 x 8 pixels. Then, the local descriptor for a particular block is defined as the average size of the feature in the same block. sections.heading: 8.3.2 Global descriptors
sections.text: The local descriptors treat each image block individually and therefore are not sufficient to provide useful information when the reactions of the characteristics are quite similar in all image blocks. For example, let's take an image full of edges, like a wavy sea. In this case, the local descriptor associated with the image margins cannot provide useful information about prominent objects in the scene, as all blocks provide upright-edged replies. The proposed system can overcome this problem by using global descriptions. The uniqueness of a block can be evaluated by the absolute difference in the reaction of the characteristics between this block and the other blocks of the image. sections.heading: 8.3.3 Window descriptors
sections.text: Local and global descriptors are able to highlight image blocks that differ greatly in terms of the response of the characteristics or have a unique presence in the image. However, when potential targets are represented in more than one block, the above descriptors highlight the most dominant target and suppress the others. To solve this problem, the system uses a window descriptor that compares each image block with its adjacent blocks. The window descriptor for a block image uses an image window spanned by the maximum symmetrical distance, and along the horizontal or vertical axes, respectively. sections.heading: 8.3.4 Background subtraction
sections.text: In the case of marine surveillance, most state-of-the-art background modeling algorithms, such as Doulamis and Doulamis, 2012; Makantasis et al., 2012), fail either because of their high computing costs or because of the constantly moving background and moving cameras. However, if the background modeling algorithm 69 Maritime surveillanceDECISION MAKING VIA SEMI-SUPERVISED MACHINE LEARNING TECHNIQUES | Ph.D. is merged into a unified feature vector with the previously constructed visual attention maps, our system will be able to highlight potential threats while simultaneously suppressing parts of land that could occur in the scene by implicitly detecting motion pressure. The proposed system uses the mixtures of gaussies (MOG), background modeling techniques presented in (Zivkovic, 2004).

sections.heading: 8.5 Experimental results
sections.text: Most of the algorithms have been developed exclusively in C + + to achieve high performance; the overall system works almost in real time, 17fps, for images measuring 384 x 288 pixels. There is also code in Python8 for the construction of visual attention maps available for download; the performance of each system component has been checked separately; extracted features have been evaluated for discriminatory ability and importance; semi-supervised labels for the predictive result; and finally the binary classifier for its performance. The datasets describe real life scenarios under different weather conditions. The data consists of recorded videos from cameras installed at the port of Limassol, Cyprus, and the old port of Chania, Crete, Greece. Monocular cameras record videos depicting maritime traffic over a year.

sections.heading: 8.5.1 Evaluation of extracted features
sections.text: In this section, we will examine whether the extracted characteristics are able to adequately describe the pixels of the frame, thus providing useful information that facilitates the classification task. Furthermore, the extent to which 8 https: / / github.com / kmakantasis / poseidon _ features.git74 Decision Making via Semi-Supervised Machine Learning TechniquesEftychios Protopapadakis | TECHNICAL UNIVERSITY OF CRETEevery single feature influences the classification task (i.e., how important a feature is). Results regarding the importance of features allow us to discard some of them in order to speed up system performance. To evaluate the characteristic information, we have used the basic truthfulness data of the keyframes. The feature extraction results in a 16-dimensional feature vector for each pixel in a frame.

sections.heading: 8.5.2 Evaluation of semi-supervised labeling
sections.text: To evaluate the semi-supervised label, we assume that the manual labeling of key frames does not contain any segmentation errors. The ratio of representative samples to the ambiguously labeled samples is the only factor influencing the performance of the labeling algorithm. As shown in Figure 8.6, the labeling error is less than 2% if the ratio of representative samples to the ambiguously labeled samples is over 40%. If the ratio is less than 40%, the labeling error increases linearly, reaching 5.7% if the ratio of representative samples is 10%. The choice of an appropriate value for the ratio of representative samples is inherently dependent on the quality of the human labeling. If the labeling is the result of coarse image segmentation, a large portion of the labeled pixels bears the wrong label. In such cases, the ratio mentioned above must be set to a small value. The most representative samples from each sample are accepted as the correct label during the remaining INE label.

sections.heading: 8.6 Conclusions & future work
sections.text: The system delivers robust results by combining monitored and unmonitored methods suitable for maritime surveillance and an innovative initialization process; offline initialization of the system is achieved through a graph-based SSL algorithm that is suitable for large data sets and supports users during the segmentation process; another advantage is the automated adaptation of the system to new environments in real-time; extensive performance analysis suggests that the proposed system works well in real time, over long periods of time with no specific hardware requirements and no assumptions regarding scene, environment and / or visual conditions; such a system should support local authorities or anyone interested in maritime surveillance at no significant additional costs.Further enhancements to the system are possible in many areas. First, the integration of a target detection system would be intriguing; another idea would be to operate in parallel to other suggested methods in a coordination-based system.

sections.heading: 9 Non-destructive flaws detection in foundation piles
sections.text: In this chapter, we use the unlabeled data to improve detection accuracy for error detection in foundation piles. To achieve this, we use a graph-based approach and noise modeling techniques to map waveforms on a new distributor. Given a number of waveforms, expert help is required for only a small subset (i.e. ≤ 40% of available samples).The proposed approach reduces labeling effort, which is both costly and time consuming. Such an approach promotes data collection as a larger database improves classification accuracy. Data availability was not a problem as we used numerical simulation to generate different pile types with errors.

sections.heading: 9.1 Introduction
sections.text: Structures foundation in the form of concrete piles is a commonly used approach in many cases. These piles are usually built by the use of precast elements and cast-in-situ techniques. Sometimes "necks" or "pears" can be created in the process of drilling. These defects can affect the load-bearing capacity of the piles. Therefore, the structural evaluation and monitoring of new and existing piles is becoming increasingly important. In this chapter we deal with the detection of such defects using a graphics-based approach. Piles "surfaces" oscillations, which are generated by numerical simulation, serve as row data for the detection of mechanisms. Surface oscillation is non-destructive testing (NDT) approach (Garnier et al., 2011), adopted for many practical reasons. The test is based on wave propagation theory; the effects generate a compression wave that exceeds the pile with a constant shaft propagation.

sections.heading: 9.1.1 Related work
sections.text: The work of (Huang and Ni, 2012) examines the relative performance of the sonic echo (SE), the momentum response (IR) and the parallel seismic (PS) tests with a locally constructed pile foundation using simulated defects. The work of (Hola and Schabowicz, 2010) presents the latest approaches of NDT to building structures. Such studies suggest that the NDT approach is appropriate. Other approaches focus on the test conditions, such as the effects of the source on wave propagation (Chai et al., 2010) and provide precise results very close to real life situations. The work of (Huang et al., 2010) focuses on the identification of borehole defects. Other approaches focus on the test conditions, such as the effects of the source on wave propagation (Reliciation, Chai et al., 2010). Generally, the quality of the numerically generated waveforms is close to the actual ones.

sections.heading: 9.2 Proposed methodology
sections.text: The proposed approach is suitable for low-load integrity tests carried out in the time domain. In the time domain, the shaft is generated by a hand-held hammer blow and the reaction as a function of time is recorded by multiple acceleration sensors placed on the head of piles and around it on a circular base near the site of the hammer blow. Monitoring and analysis of these reflections form the basis of the PIT approach (Schauer and Langer, 2012).In our case, similar tests are modeled with the tests carried out in the laboratories by applying a coupled finite element method (FEM) together with the scaled finite element boundary element method (SBFEM).Numerical simulation is used for data generation, and the propagation of graph labels (Wang and Zhang, 2008) is then used for misidentification.

sections.heading: 9.2.1 Piles numerical simulation
sections.text: In order to simulate the wave propagation through the piles, a coupled FEM and SBFEM approach is used. This approach satisfies the radiation state and allows the simulation of an infinite half-space. This ensures that the applied momentum is not reflected at the limit of numerical discretion. The coupled approach requires only the discrediting of a small domain compared to a purely FEM-based approach. FEM and SBFEM are used to model the near field and the far field.

sections.heading: 9.2.3 Possible limitations
sections.text: The entire process is based on signal comparisons and covers a very limited range of defect cases. Thus, there is the possibility of ineffectiveness of features in different defect scenarios. In addition, this chapter includes case study numerically simulated pile signals; no noise due to small cavities, surface fluctuations, etc. is expected, which is a common case with actual foundation piles. The applied method for feature extraction (Figure 9.2.2) could partially cope with such noise by average operators, but this has not been tested in the real field.

sections.heading: 9.3 Experimental results
sections.text: Fault detection can be considered a classification problem. Suppose a pile is split into pieces. In addition, the available information is limited in a few waveforms that are recorded on the pile surface. We must classify each of these parts into one of three categories. The "neck" category indicates the existence of a "neck," i.e. smaller than expected. The "light bulb" category indicates the existence of a "light bulb," i.e. larger than expected. There is also the "fault-free" category, in which there are neither "light bulbs" nor "necks." sections.text: One method of assessing the behavior of a cluster is the application of non-destructive testing by using low-time integrity tests. The shaft is generated by a hand-held hammer blow and the reaction is recorded as a function of time by multiple accelerators placed on the head of the cluster and around it on a circular base near the site of the hammer blow. Then, we must apply signal processing methods to the waveforms that are generated to detect the defects. Then, these features form a graph in which the labels spread between the edges using both labeled and unlabeled data. Experiments conducted provide promising results; the error detection rate is above 80% when Z-axis observations are used. On the contrary, performance based on X- and Y-axis behavior is very low.

sections.heading: 10.1.1 Place for improvement
sections.text: The main purpose is to further refine the data sets obtained using various CBIR techniques. The reason behind the proposed mechanism is the need for multiple use of the same data sets in different applications (e.g. subsets of the same data can be used for 3D reconstruction, tourism promotion, book publications, etc.).Metafillation creates a suitable mechanism for image analysis according to the user's requirements.The entire data set is presented to the user on the basis of some representative samples, some of which the user must comment, either as relevant or irrelevant to his current search.Subsequently, a suitable distance metric is calculated in a fully automatic manner. Such a metric is used through a ranking approach to assign a score to each image of the set. Images with high values are presented to the user as most relatives of his / her needs. All images of the set are used to calculate the corresponding distance metric according to a graph-based SSL scheme.

sections.heading: 10.2 Proposed methodology
sections.text: The metafilter approach is based on three main phases: the first stage of the methodology is aimed at identifying representative samples and their annotations as relevant or irrelevant by the user; the second stage involves learning to measure distances according to custom relevance sets; and the last stage evaluates the rest of the images using both similarity and dissimilarity rankings based on the previously specified distance measurement metric.

sections.heading: 10.2.1 Data collection and feature extraction
sections.text: Data recovery is based on several parameters (including tags, location, etc.), and once the dataset is collected for a particular monument, additional features are extracted from the images. Characteristics selection is critical; low-quality features can lead to low performance as we use Euclidean approaches. Three visual MPEG-7 descriptors were used for the purposes of this research, as in (Kyriakaki et al., 2014): Color Blayout Descriptor (CLD), Scalable Color Descriptor (SCD) and Edge Histogram Descriptor (EHD). The specific descriptors were selected for their simplicity and small size, high processing speed, robustness, scalability and interoperability (Serna et al., 2011).

sections.heading: 10.2.2 Mathematical formulation
sections.text: The meta-filter approach, which is based on an overall concept for each image, is described by the following equation: "It is about an overall picture," "It is about an overall picture," "It is about an overall picture," "It is about an overall picture," "It is about an overall picture," "It is about an overall picture," "It is about an overall picture," "It is about an overall picture," "It is about an overall picture," "It is about an overall picture," "It is about an overall picture."

sections.heading: 10.2.3 User involvement
sections.text: Instead of sending random samples to the user, or allowing him to quickly scan the retrieved images, a suitable but complicated approach is chosen for selecting the best paradises. Thus, the OPTICS algorithm (Daszykowski et al., 2004) is used to search for the densest clusters. Density values are obtained by searching for the local maxims in Figure 10.1 (a). The OPTICS algorithm requires the number of objects in the environment as a parameter.

sections.heading: 10.2.4 Possible limitations
sections.text: The proposed methodology addresses such problems in part because the characteristics used can describe the needs of the user. However, if the choice of characteristics is left to the user; there is a variety from low (K. Makantasis et al., 2013) to high (Makantasis et al., 2014) or a combination of both. However, if the data is in a variety of high density due to poor feature selection, the distance matrix does not adequately capture the needs of the user. Otherwise (where characteristics can describe the needs of the user) we have a high retrieval rate as described in (Protopapadakis et al., 2014). Finally, it is possible that the representative images do not show what the user is looking for. In this case, we repeat the process using different image characteristics or different parameter values for the selection algorithms.

sections.heading: 10.3 Experimental results
sections.text: The code was implemented with the MatLab software and is available online for all applied methods. A typical quad-core desktop PC with 8GB RAM was used. The evaluation data sets were initially determined by the work of (Ioannides et al., 2013).

sections.heading: 10.3.1 Dataset description
sections.text: The evaluation data refer specifically to three cultural monuments: Knossos, Porta Nigra and Fontana dei Quatro Fummi. Knossos is the largest Bronze Age excavation site in Crete, Greece, and is considered Europe's oldest city. The set consists of 1392 images and the special category refers to wall drawings. Porta Nigra (Black Gate) is a large Roman city gate in Trier, Germany. It is today the largest Roman city gate north of the Alps. It was designed in 1651 by Gian Lorenzo Bernini for Pope Innocence X and contains 133 images and the special category refers to interior shots. Fontana dei Quatro Fummi (Fountain of the Four Rivers) is a fountain on Piazza Navona in Rome, Italy. The set contains irrelevant images and the special category refers to night shots and grayscale images. For each monument, four cases of image filtration, i.e. the Ezios, are briefly described as relevant for different characteristics (according to Fmi).
